content.say: Start by paying attention to the sensations of breathing.
Notice how the body is moving gently.
The chest, rising and falling.
Notice the sensation of the air entering through the nose, brushing the upper lip.
Become very curious about whatever sensation appears.
Just stay here for a moment, observing the breath in this area between your nose and your upper lip.
Now, shift your focus to a different area.
If you were focusing on the tip of the nose, perhaps feel the breath in the back of the throat, or deep in the belly.
Stay there for a moment as well, just observing.
Now, quickly look back at who is looking.
Who is doing the observation?
Is there anything there?
As soon as you look, notice the shift in perspective.
And then, simply go back, resting in that awareness.
You may discover that suddenly, there is only the breathing.
When you glance back and direct your attention at the breathing, it feels different. Notice which way feels more authentic.
If it doesn't feel like that, it is okay. Simply return to observing the sensations.
Whatever sensation appears in consciousness, accept it and pay attention.
Look very closely at the raw sensation. What does it actually feel like?
Notice the texture. Is there a beginning to the sensation?
And again, quickly look back. Glance.
Is there anybody pointing the attention?
Just relax into observation.
Now, notice that although the eyes are closed, there is still light behind the eyes.
Bring your focus to that area, as though you are looking into a vastness of space.
You are still feeling the breath, but now there is this vision involved. It is undefined. Undetermined.
You cannot really name what you are seeing, so just rest with that seeing.
If you notice a thought intruding upon this, just be really curious in that moment.
Are you suddenly seeing the thought? Is there a beginning to that thought?
When you are seeing the space behind your eyes and observing the breath, does the thought still exist?
If you are still observing the space, I invite you to quickly look back and see who is looking through those eyes.
Is that a feeling? A sensation? Is there anything there?
And then go back to just looking. Just feeling.
Now, just relax and let whatever sensation appears flow through this open awareness.
Your awareness is the sky, and different sensations are the phenomena that appear and disappear like clouds.
Or perhaps, you are the ocean, and the phenomena are the waves.
You are a mountain, and the phenomena are different plants or animals on the mountain.
You are very solid. Unmoving.
Take that position in open awareness.
Whatever comes, you remain unmoved. You are simply observing and welcoming.
There is a relationship between you and the sensations; a friendship of sorts.
Check your body posture. Is it relaxed? Are you sitting with noble silence?
If there is any tension, willfully adjust the posture so it is easier to sit.
Mindfully adjust, remembering the attitude of curiosity. Wanting to know the very flavor of these sensations.
Whatever is arising, remain curious, but without effort.
Just relaxing, and letting the sensations wash over you.
In these last few minutes, gently open your eyes and see the same world rushing in.
Observe all of that with the same equanimity, the same attention.
Be curious about what it actually is. Is it shapes? Colors?
Open the gaze wide.
Notice the thoughts. They are automatic, but that is okay, because they are just like the clouds.
Just like the waves.
You remain unmoved.
